title: Monday, 4th April, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
PM

Morning

PM

Sorry we're late

PM

Reasons

11:04 am
PM

Not least the Panama papers

PM

So here's where this has led me so far...

PM

11:04 am
PM

That's Birgitta Jónsdóttir

PM

Leads the Pirates Party in Iceland

PM

And given that the Pirates party there draws more support than all the other main political parties put together...

11:05 am
PM

It's looking good for Birgitta

PM

Did you know Iceland had a Pirates Party Bryce?

PM

I didn't

11:06 am
BE

I did.

PM

Yeah, should have known that

PM

Do you know about the letter (Þ

11:06 am
PM

???

BE

Uh, no. Apart from it being the party logo.

PM

The Pirate Party (Icelandic: Píratar) is a political party in Iceland. The party was cofounded on November 24, 2012[2][3] by Birgitta Jónsdóttir (previously a member of The Movement), and several prominent Internet activists, including Smári McCarthy.

They successfully applied for the ballot list letter Þ in order to run in the 2013 Icelandic parliamentary election. This marks their first electoral participation as well as the first party to request the letter Þ.

11:07 am
PM

This article needs additional citations for verification. Please help improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. (December 2009)

Upper- and lower-case versions of the thorn character
Thorn or þorn (Þ, þ) is a letter in the Old English, Gothic, Old Norse and modern Icelandic alphabets, as well as some dialects of Middle English.

PM

It is pronounced as either a voiceless dental fricative [θ] or the voiced counterpart of it [ð].

PM

voiceless dental fricative

11:08 am
BE

I'm none the wiser.

PM

Anyway,

PM

You need this link for the Panama stuff

(Back when we used those.)

PM

BE

11:11 am

Actually, worth following the wikileaks twitter on this -- they have lots of good links

https://twitter.com/wikileaks

But this is going to go on for weeks

BE

(@Mouselet: I'll bow to your superior maths skills.)

Weeks and weeks

BE

And every single day will be fun, for those of us who haven't tried to hide money offshore.

BE

Which I think is most of us, right? Even in this audience.

PM

(cleverhedge -- we thought that, initially, but if you look at the map there are 3k US related companies in the cache )

On 30 March 2016 the Federal Antimonopoly Service of the Russian Federation ("FAS") announced in a press release that it had initiated an investigation into Mondi Syktyvkar for violation of the antimonopoly law in respect of the pricing of offset paper. Mondi has not yet received any FAS notification to this effect and has no further details of the investigation at this stage.

11:17 am
PM

Allegedly operating a cartel in offset paper.

BE

........................ Offset paper?

PM

Mondi is committed to complying with all applicable antimonopoly laws and believes it has not violated any such laws.

11:18 am

Woodfree uncoated paper

PM

Apparently

One day I'll learn about the paper industry. Not today though.

11:19 am
BE

BE

As is always the case with antimonopoly investigations, it is difficult to make a
judgement on such news but it is encouraging to see Mondi firmly saying it believes
it has been compliant. This follows a similar statement from Mondi two weeks ago
when it responded to a European investigation of the kraft paper and industrial
bags sector.

And Davy.

BE

The
open-cast operation is relatively small in Anglo’s  Australian metcoal portfolio. Anglo bought its 70% stake in the mine (minorities are POSCO and Itochu) in 
2007 for $620m. The mine was part of the package of coal assets Anglo decided to divest in Australia including Callide (sold in January this year for an
undisclosed amount) and Dartbrook. 

BE

Overall the sale is a small positive in that it moves on the process of streamlining Anglo's portfolio and reducing debt

11:24 am
BE

Which is inarguable, I guess.

undefined

(@Airborne: gold star. You're so much better than us this morning, it's a bit embarrassing.)

People's QE

Official QE mends the banks balance sheets, so they in turn can pass money to those customers daft enough to say yes to PPI

PM

hmm

BE

11:28 am
PM

Yes, of course

BE

I'm not sure the big PFCA data entirely matches the trends, but I'm no expert.

BE

Here's what Deutsche wrote about it last week.

11:29 am
BE

January PPI payout data: down MoM and YoY
The FCA had released data on PPI payouts for January 2016 (Figure 1 ). Payouts in
January were £311.8m – down MoM and YoY, and at around the same level as in
summer 2015. Overall, redress payments have continued a generally stable trend since
2014 of £300-400m/month. Recent Google Trends data (search volumes for the term
‘PPI’ within the UK) indicated a spike in activity in January, but this appears to have
reduced in February & March to around the avg. level of the last 2 years (30-40% of peak
volume). Overall we see the most recent data as generally supportive: PPI claims have
not trended significantly higher since the announcement of the cut-off date for PPI (mid-
2018). We expect PPI claims to remain at around the £300-350m level over the coming
months and the most recent data is supportive of this.

BE

 The UK banks all took top-ups to PPI at 4Q15: Lloyds (£2.1bn), Barclays (£1.45bn),
RBS (£500m), HSBC ($350m), Santander UK (£450m) designed to cover the
proposed deadline in mid-2018, new rules and guidance in light of Plevin Supreme
Court decision. We have an additional £500m of PPI charges in for Lloyds and
Barclays in 4Q16 forecasts.
 Of the UK banks, Lloyds sold the largest volume of PPI products (an estimated 16
million policies since 2000), and has so far taken almost £16bn of provisions,
including £2.1bn in 4Q15. Each additional £1bn beyond what is in our forecasts
represents around 1.4p off TNAV or c.44bps of CET1.

PM

thx for that

Chapel Down’s fast-growing beer and cider business, Curious Drinks, has raised more than £1.7m through Seedrs equity crowdfunding campaign and share placing
£1.16m raised through equity crowdfunding, £550k through share placing
895 Curious Drinks enthusiasts welcomed as shareholders
The EIS qualifying Placing to remain open (for investments over £25,000) until 29th April 2016
Funds will enable Curious Drinks to meet growing demand from both the UK and internationally and proceed with building a brewery

IF YOU INVEST £100:

◆ An annual guided tour of either the Curious Brewery or the Chapel Down Winery in Tenterden for two people
◆ A Curious metal pin badge
◆ Shareholder information pack in presentation wallet

IF YOU INVEST £500:

All the benefits of £100, plus:

◆ A Curious glass
◆ A bottle of limited edition Curiouser and Curiouser’ beer*
◆ An ongoing 25% discount for purchases of Curious beer and cider

Clearly, this is in the Jackie Membership Club class of investment perks.

hahaha

IF YOU INVEST £1,000:

◆ An ongoing 25% discount for purchases of Curious beer and cider
◆ An ongoing 25% discount off dining and drinking at the Curious Brewery
◆ An ongoing 25% discount off Chapel Down wines
◆ A bottle of limited edition‘Curiouser and Curiouser’ beer*
◆ Three limited edition Spieglau beer glasses, comprising a specially designed Lager, IPA and Porter glass
◆ A private tour and personalised tasting at the Curious Brewery for four people each year
◆ A preferential gold discount card offering preferential privileges at the Curious Brewery

IF YOU INVEST £25,000:

All the benefits of £1,000, plus:

◆ Investor’s name etched onto a fermentation tank
◆ Exclusive invitation to the Curious Brewery with private tour of the brewery before it’s open to the public
◆ Six bottles of limited edition ‘Curiouser and Curiouser’ beer each year*
◆ Six special edition bottles of Curious Brew lager from the first production run at the Curious Brewery with personalised label and handsigned by the team
◆ A preferential platinum discount card offering further preferential privileges at the Curious Brewery

We believe that the step up in international hotel M&A and rejuvenated
speculation surrounding a spin-off of Costa Coffee now limit the valuation
downside. While earnings risk remains (we are cutting our estimates by 5-6%),
we believe that the risk/reward profile is now more balanced. Hence we move
our recommendation to HOLD, ahead of Whitbread’s scheduled preliminary
results and capital markets day on 26 April. We re-set our target price to 3800p
(from 4100p), in-line with our sum-of-the-parts methodology.
